Award.AwardTitle: Building the National Cyber Workforce: New SFS Program at Kansas State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project launches the CyberCorpsÂ®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at Kansas State University (K-State), designated by NSA and DHS as a National Center of Academic Excellence of Cybersecurity Research (CAE-R). The new SFS program at Kansas State University provides highly valuable and timely education and career opportunities for a large student body interested in cybersecurity and information assurance. It builds upon existing strong research and education programs at K-State, and is intended to attract a steady stream of about six incoming SFS scholars per year. The project builds a scholarship program that emphasizes personalized programs of study and individual, one-on-one mentoring throughout students' academic careers, including job search and placement. The project team leverages their ties with other regional schools and proximity to military bases like Fort Riley and Fort Leavenworth to recruit students of all ages and backgrounds, targeting a uniquely diverse, under-served, and underrepresented population. A major feature of the program design is an emphasis on close faculty/student interaction. Each student has an SFS faculty mentor who works closely with the student to develop an individualized study plan, monitors progress, helps the student formulate a career plan and provides advice and assistance in looking for employment both for internships and final placement after graduation. This hands-on, personalized approach helps ensure retention and quality learning.

This SFS project involves the participation of the Manhattan Area Technical College.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CyberCorps SFS program at Kansas State University has awarded 26 scholarships to a mix of bachelors, masters, and doctoral students. All graduates have secured jobs in diverse government roles including academia, qasi-governmental institutions, national labs, the armed forces, and the NSA. The program contributed to significantly increased overall interest and engagement in cybersecurity at KSU, beyond just those students who received scholarships. The number of students enrolled in security courses was 80-95% higher than the number of scholarship recipients.

 

The resulting student influx has led to the expansion and realignment of KSU's cybersecurity curriculum, which now includes more courses, which when combined make up an "option" track for undergraduates who want to specialize in cybersecurity. Increased student participation has also raised the profile of our Cyber Defense Club competition team, who have performed exceptionally well in recent cyber defense competitions such as Iowa State National Cyber Defense Competition (second place in 2014 and 2018, third place in 2015), Cyber Force (second place in 2017 and 2018), and CANSec (first place in 2015 and 2016, second place in 2019). The Club has even hosted their own local and regional competitions.

 

Student support consisted of one-on-one mentoring and we added group "seminars" later in the program. During group meetings, mentors and SFS alumni provided help with resume writing and presentations, and current SFS students (with at least one year in the program) shared their experiences, informing their peers about potential opportunities they may have overlooked, and letting new scholars know about the available opportunities for the future. We have seen increased research participation as a result. CyberCorps SFS has also been exceptionally synergistic with our CAE-R designation, helping recruit and retain females and academically underrepresented groups.

 

Early program challenges included finding internships, since the program was just getting started and did not yet have an established network. Over its runtime, we made several major improvements to the way the program was run, including the addition of formal assessment, scheduled cohort meetings, more socialization and networking opportunities, and increased emphasis on research productivity. Assessments included a first-of-its-kind survey, developed in-house in collaboration with the PI and one of our past SFS students (peer-reviewed and published, along with additional results and validation). The study is IRB-approved, and in addition to helping evaluate the quality of the education offered as part of SFS, as well as student interest pre-admission and satisfaction at graduation, we may be able to use the results to estimate student aptitude for cybersecurity. Our students reported being active in the Cyber Defense Club, participating in research, and attending conferences, workshops, and career fairs, and having internships at federal agencies as some of the major benefits the received from the program. They expressed satisfaction (the program highly met or exceeded their expectation) and appreciation of the career assistance it provided, as well as the freedom "to concentrate on studies, research, and outreach". One scholarship recipient was able to use her time not only participating in clubs and K-12 activities, but also founding the KSU chapter of ACM-W.


Last Modified: 02/28/2020
Modified by: Eugene Y Vasserman
